data.title: 1878) – Find a Grave Gedenkstätte
data.meta_description: Italian Monarch. He was from the Royal House of Savoy and the first king of the united Italy. His Majesty's father was King Charles Albert of Piedmont-Sardinia, and his mother was Maria Theresa of Austria. He was educated by the Roman Catholic Church and had military training in preparation for becoming the king. In...
data.text:
Italian Monarch. He was from the Royal House of Savoy and the first king of the united Italy. His Majesty's father was King Charles Albert of Piedmont-Sardinia, and his mother was Maria Theresa of Austria. He was educated by the Roman Catholic Church and had military training in preparation for becoming the king. In 1849, his father abdicated the throne, and he became King Victor Emmanuel II of Piedmont-Sardinia, which was one of the many independent states within Italy with a monarch. As king, he championed the unification of all the Italian states under the leadership of Prime Minister Camillo Cavour. With the assistance of Emperor Napoleon III, Sardinia fought Austria and received the Austrian territories in Italy. A brave battlefield king, he was active in the war by commanding the troops in the Battles of Magenta and Solferino. King Victor Emmanuel II supported Giuseppe Garibaldi's conquest of the Bourbon-held Kingdom of the Two Sicilies and the Papal States. He recognized Giuseppe Mazzini's key role in the unification of Italy. Cavour was considered the "brain of unification," Mazzini the "soul," and Garibaldi the "sword." Victor Emmanuel II became King of Italy in 1861. Rome and Venetia subsequently joined the Kingdom of Italy. In 1842, he married his paternal first cousin Adelaide of Austria, and the couple had eight children. As a widower, he had a morganatic marriage to Rosa Vercellana, and the couple had two daughters. He was a highly decorated leader not only in Italy but had foreign recognition as well. Upon his death, Pius IX agreed to have him be buried at the Pantheon. After his death, his oldest son, Umberto I, became the King of Italy. Erected in 1885, a massive monument to honor him was located at the foot of the Capitoline Hill in Rome. Historians credit him with an unstable reign full of violence.
